headline.main: NEWS BY TELEGRAPH.; The Movement against Collector Schell-Great Gathering of New-York Democrats. Attempts to Defeat the Passage of the Oregon Bill. AFFAIRS AT THE NATIONAL CAPITAL. The Movement for the Election of Mr. Criltenden to the Presidency. The Central-American and Spanish-Mexican Questions. IMPORTANT GOVERNMENT DISPATEHES.

docs.lead_paragraph: The proposed meeting of gentlemen friendly to the election of Mr. CRITTENDEN to the Presidency, which was held here last evening, brought quite a number of politicians to the city. It was designed originally to be an exclusive meeting of gentlemen in opposition to the Democracy, who do not cooperate with the Republicans, but several gentlemen were invited, and piesent, whose position in the Republican Party is dcfinte.

headline.main: AFFAIRS IN THE GULF.; New and Startling View of the "Visit" on Board the Washington--Official Collision, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: There was not the least occasion for public mystification in regard to recent events on the Coast of Central America, and especially in regard to the supineness with which the Administration has received intelligence of the high-handed measures of the British force upon that coast.

docs.snippet: TWELFTH DAY--(CONCLUDED.) [FROM OUR OWN REPORTER] NEW-HAVEN, Wednesday, Dec. 15. Mrs. Ward's cross-examination was continued. Q.--What hour in the day was it that you got to the house in Dixwell-street? A.--Between 10 and 11 o'clock; I found Mrs....
docs.lead_paragraph: TWELFTH DAY--(CONCLUDED.) [FROM OUR OWN REPORTER] NEW-HAVEN, Wednesday, Dec. 15. Mrs. Ward's cross-examination was continued. Q.--What hour in the day was it that you got to the house in Dixwell-street? A.--Between 10 and 11 o'clock; I found Mrs. Bennett alone in her room; I don't know whether anybody else was on the second story; Mrs. Bennett was holding on to the front of the bedstead in great agony.

docs.snippet: THE EXHIBITION OF FAT GAITLE, , AT TATTERSALLS.--The annual exhibition of fat cattle and other stock was opened yesterday at TATTERSALLS, corner of Sixth-avenue and Thirty-ninth-street. The collection was not very large, but in other respects...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE EXHIBITION OF FAT GAITLE, , AT TATTERSALLS.--The annual exhibition of fat cattle and other stock was opened yesterday at TATTERSALLS, corner of Sixth-avenue and Thirty-ninth-street. The collection was not very large, but in other respects compares very favorably with previous shows.

docs.snippet: The report of the Committee on Finance, presented to the Board last evening, in favor of donating $1,000 to the New-York Eye and Ear Infirmary, was adopted. The Committee on Roads reported in favor of opening and grading Eleventh-avenue, from...
docs.lead_paragraph: The report of the Committee on Finance, presented to the Board last evening, in favor of donating $1,000 to the New-York Eye and Ear Infirmary, was adopted. The Committee on Roads reported in favor of opening and grading Eleventh-avenue, from Twenty-fifth-street to its southern extremity, and the report was adopted.

headline.main: NEWS BY TELEGRAPH; Refusal of the House to Impeach Judge Watrous. PACIFIC SOLUTION PROBABLE. IMPORTANT FROM WASHINGTON. The British Visit to the Washington. SPECIAL MESSAGE OF THE PRESIDENT. Correspondence Between Commodore McIntosh and the British Commander.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives, to-day by a vote of 91 to 111, refused to institute an impeachment against Judge WATROUS, of Texas. Many members who entertained strong suspicion of corruption yet voted against impeachment, as they regarded the evidence as insufficient to justify any hope of conviction by the Senate. Judge WATROUS, it is rumored, will immediately resign.

docs.snippet: SENATOR SUMNER AGAIN.--A letter from Dr. HEYWOOD, in Paris, to Senator WILSON, states that Mr. SUMNER will spend the coming Winter in France. His seat in the Senate will remain vacant, therefore, during the coming session, unless he resigns, and thus...
docs.lead_paragraph: SENATOR SUMNER AGAIN.--A letter from Dr. HEYWOOD, in Paris, to Senator WILSON, states that Mr. SUMNER will spend the coming Winter in France. His seat in the Senate will remain vacant, therefore, during the coming session, unless he resigns, and thus allows Massachusetts the benefit of a full representation in that body. We hope he will conclude to do so.

headline.main: CITY INTELLIGENCE.; Governors of the Almshouse. Police Reports. Coroners' Inquests.

docs.lead_paragraph: LIGHTS AND SHADOWS FROM COURTS AND JURY ROOMS.--Mr. A. OAKEY HALL lectured upon this subject in the Cooper Institute on Monday evening. The topic was one upon which, of all others, Mr. HALL is most qualified to speak. His professional reputation, and the general interest felt in the subject, drew together quite a numerous audience in spite of the unfavorable weather.
